Additional JavaScript Notes

Mozilla JavaScript Dev Guide

These notes are handwritten notes from the JS development guides found on Mozilla.org.

Switch Statements

What are Switch Statements

switch (expression) {
    case: Label_1:
    statements_1
    [break;]
    case: Label_2:
    statements_2
    [break;]
    ...
    default:
    statements_def
    [break;]
}

Switch statements explained

First the program looks for a case clause with a label matching the value of the expression and then transfers control to that clause, executing the associated statements.

If no matching label is found, the program looks for the optional default clause:

  • If a default clause is found, the program transfers control to that clause, executing the associated statements.
  • If no default clause is found, the program resumes execution at the statement following the end of the switch.
  • (By convention, the default clause is written as the last clause, but it does not need to be so.)

Switch statement example

switch (fruittypes) {
    case 'Oranges':
    console.log('Oranges are $0.43 a pound.');
    break;
    case 'Apples':
    console.log('Apples are $0.23 a pound.');
    break;
    case 'Pears':
    console.log('Pears are $0.76 a pound.');
    break;
    default:
    console.log(`Sorry, all sold out of ${fruittype}.`)
}
console.log("Is there anything else you'd like?");

Exception Handling Statements

try...catch & throw

throw statement

Use the throw statement to throw an exception. A throw statement specifies the value to be thrown:

throw expression;

You may throw any expression, not just expressions of a specific type. the following code throws several exceptions of varying types:

throw 'Error2'; //String
throw 43; //Number
throw true //Boolean
throw {toString: function() { return "I'm an object." } }; //Object

Specifying a new object with throw

You can specify an object when you throw an exception. You can then reference the object's properties in the catch block.

// Create an object type UserException
function UserExeption(message) {
    this.message = message;
    this.name = 'UserException';
}

//Make a the exception convert to a pretty string when used as a string
// (e.g., by the error console)
UserException.prototype.toString = () => {
    return `${this.name}: "${this.message}"`;
}

//Create an instance of the object type and throw it
throw new UserException('Value too high');

try...catch statement

The try...catch statement marks a block of statements to try, and specifies one or more responses should an exception be thrown. If an exception is thrown, the try...catch statement catches it.

The try...catch statement consists of the try block, which contains one or more statements, and a catch block, containing statements that specify what to do if an exception is thrown in the try block.

In other words, you want the try block to succeedâ€”but if it does not, you want control to pass to the catch block. If any statement within the try block (or in a function called from within the try block) throws an exception, control immediately shifts to the catch block. If no exception is thrown in the try block, the catch block is skipped. The finally block executes after the try and catch blocks execute but before the statements following the try...catch statement.

Examples of try...catch

The following example uses a try...catch statement. The example calls a function that retrieves a month name from an array based on the value passed to the function. If the value does not correspond to a month number (1-12), an exception is thrown with the value "InvalidMonthNo" and the statements in the catch block set the monthName variable to unknown.

function getMonthName(mo) {
    mo = mo - 1; // Adjust month number for array index
    let months = ['Jan', 'Feb', 'Mar', 'Apr', 'May', 'Jun', 'Jul', 'Aug', 'Sep', 'Oct', 'Nov', 'Dec'];
    if (months[mo]) {
        return months[mo];
    } else {
        throw 'InvalidMonthNo'; //throw keyword is used here
    }
}

try { // Statement to try
    monthName = getMonthName(myMonth); // function could throw exception
}
catch (e) {
    monthName = 'unknown';
    logMyErrors(e); // pass exception object to error handler (i.e. your own function)
}

The catch block

You can use a catch block to handle all exceptions that may be generated in the try block.

catch (catchID) {
    statements
}

The catch block specifies an identifier (catchID in the preceding syntax) that holds the value specified by the throw statement. You can use this identifier to get information about the exception that was thrown.

JavaScript creates this identifier when the catch block is entered. The identifier lasts only for the duration of the catch block. Once the catch block finishes executing the identifier no longer exists.

catch block example

For example, the following code throws an exception. When the exception occurs, control transfers to the catch block.

try {
    throw 'myException'; // generates an exception
}
catch (err) {
    // statements to handle any exceptions
    logMyErrors(err); // pass exception object to error handler
}

Best practice: When logging errors to the console inside a catch block, using console.error() rather than console.log() is advised for debugging. It formats the message as an error, and adds it to the list of error messages generated by the page.

The finally block

The finally block contains statements to be executed after the try and catch blocks execute. Additionally, the finally block executes before the code that follows the try...catch...finally statement.

It is also important to note that the finally block will execute wether or not an exception is thrown. If an exception is thrown, however, the statements in the finally block execute even if no catch block handles the exception that was thrown.

You can use the finally block to make your script fail gracefully when an exception occurs. For example, you may need to release a resource that your script has tied up.

finally block example

The following example opens a file and then executes statements that use the file. (Using server-side JS.) If an exception is thrown while the file is open, the finally block closes the file before the script fails. Using finally here ensures that the file is never left open, even if an error occurs.

openMyFile();
try {
    writeMyFile(theData); // This may throw an error
} catch (e) {
    handleError(e); // If an error occured, handle it
} finally {
    closeMyFile(); // Always close the resource
}

Overwriting of return values by the finally block also applies to exceptions thrown or rethrown inside of the catch block:

function f() {
    try {
        throw 'bogus';
    } catch(e) {
        console.log('caught inner "bogus"');
        throw e; // this throw statement is suspended until `finally` block has completed
    } finally {
        return false; // overwrites the previous `throw`
    }
    // `return false` is executed now
}

try {
    console.log(f());
} catch(e) {
    // this is never reached!
    // while f() executes, the `finally` block returns false, which overwrites the `throw` inside the above `catch`
    console.log('caught outer "bogus"');
}

// OUTPUT
// caught inner "bogus"
// false

Nesting try...catch statements

You can nest one or more try...catch statements.

If an inner try...catch statement does not have a catch block:

  1. it must contain a finally block, and
  2. the enclosing try...catch statement's catch block is checked for a match.

Utilizing Error objects

Depending on the tupe of error, you may be able to user the name and message properties to get a more refined message.

The name property provides the general class of Error (such as DOMException or Error), while message generally provides a more succinct message than one would get by converting error object to a string.

If you are throwing your own exceptions, in order to take advantage of these properties (such as if your catch block doesn't discriminate between your own exceptions and system ones), you can use the Error constructor.

For example:

function doSomethingErrorProne() {
    if (ourCodeMakesAMistake()) {
        throw (new Error('The Message'));
    } else {
        doSomethingToGetAJavascriptError();
    }
}

try {
    doSomethingErrorProne();
} catch (e) {                   // NOW, we actually use `console.error()`
    console.error(e.name);      // logs 'Error"
    console.error(e.message);   // logs 'The message', or a JavaScript error message
}

labeled statement

A label provides a statement with an identifier that lets you refer to it elsewhere in your program. For example, you can use a label to identify a loop, and then use the break or continue statements to indicate whether a program should interrupt the loop or continue its execution.

The syntax looks like:

label :
    statement

The value of label may be any JS identifier that is not a reserved word. The statement that you identify with the label may be any statement.

label example

markLoop:
while (theMark === true) {
    doSomething();
}

break & continue with label

Break

A break statement terminates a loop (while, do-while, for, switch) immediately.

When using break with a lable, it terminates the specified labeled statement.

break; // terminates the innermost enclosing loop or `switch`
break [label]; // terminates the specified enclosing labeled statement
Example: breaking to a label
let x = 0;
let z = 0;
labelCancelLoops: while (true) {
    console.log('Outer loops: ' + x);
    x += 1;
    z = 1;
    while (true) {
        console.log('Inner loops: ' + z);
        z += 1;
        if (z === 10 && x === 10) {
            break labelCancelLoops;
        } else if (z === 10) {
            break;
        }
    }
}

Continue

A continue statement is used to restart a while, do-while, for, or label statement.

When used with a label, it applies to the looping statement identified with that label.

continue [label];
Example: continuing to a label

The example shows a while loop with a continue statement that executes when the value of i is 3. Thus, n takes on th evalues of 1, 3, 7, 12. 

//With continue================
let i = 0;
let n = 0;
while (i < 5) {
    i++;
    if (i === 3) {
        continue;
    }
    n += i;
    console.log(n);
}
// 1, 3, 7, 12


//Without continue==============
let i = 0;
let n = 0;
while (i < 5) {
    i++;
    if (i === 3) {
        // continue;
    }
    n += i;
    console.log(n);
}
// 1, 3, 6, 10, 15

In example 2, a statement labeled checkiandj contains a statement labeled checkj. If continue is encountered, the program terminates the current iteration of checkj and begins the next iteration.

Each time continue is encountered, checkj reiterates until its condition returns false. Then the remainder of the checkiandj statement is completed and checkiandj reiterates until its condition returns false. When false is returned, the program continues at the statement following checkiandj.

If continue had a label of checkiandj, the program would continue at the top of the checkiandj statement.

let i = 0;
let j = 10;
checkiandj:
    while (i < 4) {
        console.log(i);
        i += 1;
        checkj:
            while (j > 4) {
                console.log(j);
                j -= 1;
                if ((j % 2) === 0) {
                    continue checkj; //continues from `checkj` instead of `checkiandj`
                }
                console.log(j+ ' is odd.');
            }
            console.log('i = ' + i);
            console.log('j = ' + j);
    }

for...in statement

...iterates a specified variable over all the enumerable properties of an object. For each distinct property, JavaScript executes the specific statements. A for...in statement looks as follows:

for (variable in object)
    statement

The function bellow takes as its argument an object and the object's name. It then iterates over all the object's properties and returns a string that lists the property names and their values.

function dump_props(obj, obj_name) {
    let result = '';
    for (let i in obj) {
        result += obj_name + '.' + i + '=' + obj[i] + '<br>';
    }
    result += '<hr>';
    return result;
}

for an object car with properties make and model, result would be:

car.make = Ford
car.model = Mustang

for...in with arrays

With arrays it is still better to use a traditional for loop with a numeric index, because the for...in statement iterates over user-defined properties in addition to the array element, if you modify the array object (such as adding custom properties or methods).

for...of statement

...creates a loop iterating over iterable objects (including array, map, set, arguments object and so on), invoking a custom iteration hook with statements to be executed for the value of each distinct property.

for (variable of object)
    statement

The example shows the different between for...of and for...in. While for...in iterates over property names, for...of iterates over property values. 

const arr = [3, 5, 7];
arr.foo = 'hello';

// for...in=========
for (let i in arr) {
    console.log(i); // logs '0', '1', '2', 'foo'
}

//for...of==========
for (let i of arr) {
    console.log(i); // logs 3, 5, 7
}

Working With Objects

Creating new objects using constructor function

Using a constructor function, you can create a new object in 2 steps:

  1. Write a constructor function to define the object type. Use a capital letter for the naming!
  2. Create an instance of the object with new.

For example:

// Establish an object for cars with make, model and year:
function Car(make, model, year) {
    this.make = make;
    this.model = model;
    this.year = year;
}


// Use the constructor to create a new instance of Car:
var myCar = new Car('Eagle', 'Talon TSi', 1993);

var kensCar = new Car('Nissan', '300ZX', 1992);

Using the Object.create method

Another way to create objects is the Object.create() method, which allows you to choose the prototype object for the object you want to create, without having to define a constructor function.

var Animal = {
    type: 'Invertebrates', // Default value properties
    displayType: function () {
        console.log(this.type); // Method to display type
    }
};


// CREATE A NEW ANIMAL:
var animal1 = Object.create(Animal);
animal1.displayType(); // Output: 'invertibrates'

// CREATE A NEW ANIMAL TYPE CALLED FISHES
var fish = Object.create(Animal);
fish.type = 'Fishes';
fish.displayType(); // Output: 'Fishes"

Defining properties for an object type

You can add properties to a previously defined object type by using the prototype property. It applies to all objects inheriting that prototype.

Example:

Car.prototype.color = null; // Adds a property of color to the original Car object

car1.color = 'black'; // Adjusts the color property for car1

Defining getters and setters

A getter is a method that gets the value of a specific property. A setter is a method that sets the value of a specific property.

They can be:

  • defined using object initializers, or
  • added later to any object at any time using a getter or setter adding method.

Example with object initilizer:

var o = {
    a: 7,
    get b() {
        return this.a + 1;
    },
    set c(x) {
        this.a = x / 2;
    }
};


console.log(o.a); //7
console.log(o.b)  //8 <-- at this point the get b() method is initiated.
o.c = 50;         // <-- inititates the set c(x) method.
console.log(o.a)  // 25

Defining a class in JavaScript

A class in JavaScript consists of a class definition, in which you can specify special methods, called constructors, that creat new instances of that class.

In JavaScript the class definition and the class constructor combine into a single constructor function with an initial set of properties and values. This works with any JavaScript function, using the new keyword.

Subclasses and inheritance

In the heirarchy of classes, subclasses inherit all properties from a superclass, with additional properties and values being added or modified.

JavaScript implements inheritance by allowing association with a prototypical object with any constructor function. For example, from an Employee superclass, you can create the Manager subclass as a new class derived from the employee.prototype. It will inherit the original properties from Employee.

Adding and removing properties

Unlike other class-based languages, in JavaScript it is possible to add or remove properties from an class at any time. Even after a class is defined, you can add new properties to a class, which will also be inherited by its potential subclasses.

Creating a hierarchy

Employee superclass:

function Employee() {
    this.name = '';
    this.dept = 'general';
}

The Manager and WorkerBee definitions show the difference in how to specify the next object higher in the inheritance chain. In JavaScript, you add a prototypical instance as the value of the prototype property of the constructor function, then override the prototype.constructor to the constructor function. You can do so at any time after you define the constructor.

function Manager () {
    // This block adds an additional property on top of the properties of the employee object
    Employee.call(this);
    this.reports = [];
}
// This step copies the properties from the `Employee` prototype to the `Manager` prototype...
Manager.prototype = Object.create(Employee.prototype);
// ...which is then defined as its own object `Manager`.
Manager.prototype.constructor = Manager;


function WorkerBee() {
    Employee.call(this);
    this.projects = [];
}
// New objects can be defined at any point, even after the object method:
WorkerBee.prototype = Object.create(Employee.prototype);
WorkerBee.prototype.constructor = WorkerBee;

In this example, the call() method is used to allow a function from another object to be assigned for a different object. call() provides a new value of this to the function/method of the Manager and WorkerBee objects. It allows a method to be written once and then be inherited in another object, without rewriting the method for the new object. call() allows for multiple arguments to be passed at once, unlike apply(), which will only accept one argument.

Going from the WorkerBee class, Engineer and SalesPerson inherit from both WorkerBee and Employee as their superclasses. They have the properties of all objects above them.

function SalesPerson() {
    WorkerBee.call(this);
    this.dept = 'sales';
    this.quota = 100;
}
SalesPerson.prototype = Object.create(WorkerBee.prototype);
SalesPerson.prototype.constructor = SalesPerson;


function Engineer() {
    WorkerBee.call(this);
    this.dept = 'engineering';
    this.machine = '';
}
Engineer.prototype = Object.create(WorkerBee.prototype);
Engineer.prototype.constructor = Engineer;

Creating objects with simple definitions

The following hierarchy is created using the code below.

var jim = new Employee;
// Parenthesis can be omitted if the constructor takes no arguments.
// Jim.name is ''
// jim.dept is 'general'

var sally = new Manager;
// sally.name is ''
// sally.dept is 'general'
// sally.reports is []

var mark = new WorkerBee;
// mark.name is ''
// mark.dept is 'general'
// mark.project is []

var fred = new SalesPerson;
// fred.name is ''
// fred.dept is 'sales'
//fred.projects is []
// fred.quota is 100

var jane = new Engineer;
// jane.name is ''
// jane dept is 'engineering'
// jane.projects is []
// jane.machine is ''

Individual objects = Jim, Sally, Mark, Fred, Jane, etc.

Object properties

This section discusses how objects inherit properties from other objects in the prototype chain and what happens when you add a property at run time.

Inheriting properties

Consider:

var mark = new WorkerBee;

Resulting in a new object:

mark.name = '';
mark.dept = 'general';
mark.projects = [];

The generic properties that mark inherited from WorkerBee can be altered without affecting the original prototype.

Adding properties

In JavaScript, properties can be added to objects at any time, like so:

mark.bonus = 3000;

// This only adds the `bonus` property to Mark, not any other employee.

Employee.prototype.specialty = 'none';

// This adds the property `specialty` to all objects using the `Employee.prototype`.

The diagram shows how prototype properties can be overridden by subclasses, leaving the properties of superclasses untouched.

More flexible constructors

The constructor functions shown so far do not let you specify property values when you create an instance. You can provide arguments to constructors to initialize property values for instances. The following figure shows one way to do this.

function Employee (name, dept) {
    this.name = name || '';
    this.dept = dept || 'general';
}

// name and dept will be written if arguments are provided. If not, then it will use the default.

function WorkerBee (projs) {
    this.projects = projs || [];
}
WorkerBee.prototype = new Employee;

function Engineer(mach) {
    this.dept = 'engineering';
    this.machine = mach || '';
}
Engineer.prototype = new WorkerBee;

Using || may not work as expected if the constructor function is called with arguments which convert to false (like 0) and empty string (""). In this case the default value will be chosen.

With these definitions, when you create an instance of an object, you can specify values for the locally defined properties. You can use the following statement to create a new Engineer:

var jane = new Engineer('belau');

// jane.name == '';
// jane.dept == 'engineering';
// jane.projects == [];
// jane.machine == 'belau';

You can have the constructor add more properties by directly calling the constructor function for an object higher in the prototype chain. The following figure shows these new definitions.

In detail, this is the new definition for the Engineer constructor:

function Engineer(name, projs, mach) {
    this.base = WorkerBee;
    this.base(name, 'engineering', projs);
    this.maching = mach || '';
}

Suppose you create a new Engineer object as follows:

var jane = new Engineer('Doe, Jane',['navigator', 'javascript'], 'belau');

JavaScript follows these steps:

  1. The new operator create a generic objects and sets its __proto__ property to Engineer.prototype.
  2. The new operator passes the new object to the Engineer constructor as the value of the this keyword.
  3. The constructor creates a new property called base for that object and assigns the value of the WorkerBee constructor to the base property. This makes the WorkerBee constructore a method of the Engineer objects. The name of the base property is not special. You can use any legal property name; base is simply an example.
  4. The constructor calls the base method, passing as its arguments two of the arguments passed to the constructor ("Doe, Jane" and ['navigator', 'javascript']) and also a string "engineering". Explicitly using "engineering" in the constructor indicates that all Engineer objects have the same value for the inherited dept property, and this value overrides the value inherited from Employee.
  5. Because base is a method of Engineer, whithing the call to base, JavaScript binds the this keyword to the object created in Step 1. Thus, the WorkerBee function in turn passes the "Doe, Jane" and "engineering" arguments to the Employee constructor function.
  6. Upon return from the base method, the Engineer constructor initializes the object's machine property to "belau".
  7. Upon return from the constructor, JavaScript assigns the new object to the jane variable.

You have to explicitly set up the prototype to ensure dynamic inheritance.

function Engineeer(name, projs, mach) {
    this.base = WorkerBee;
    this.base(name, 'engineering', projs);
    this.machine = mach || '';
}
var jane = new Engineer('Doe, Jane', ['navigator', 'javascript'], 'belau');
Employee.prototype.specialty = 'none';

// The jane object does not inherit the specialty property. You still need to explicitly set up the prototype to ensure dynamic inheritance.

Instead, do this:

function Engineer(name, projs, mach) {
    // Setting up the object Engineer
    this.base = WorkerBee;
    this.base(name, 'engineering', projs);
    this.machine = mach || '';
}
Engineer.prototype = new WorkerBee;
var jane = new Engineer('Doe, Jane', ['navigator', 'javascript'], 'belau');
Employee.prototype.specialty = 'none';
// Now the value of the jane objects' specialty property is 'none'.

Another way of inheriting is by using the call() / apply() methods, like so: 

function Engineer(name, projs, mach) {
    this.base = WorkerBee;
    this.base(name, 'engineering', projs);
    this.machine = mach || '';
}

function Engineer(name, projs, mach) {
    WorkerBee.call(this, name, 'engineering', projs);
    this.machine = mach || '';
}

// Using the `call()` method makes a cleaner implementation because the `base` is not needed anymore.
